Now we can construct a rigorous criterion for whether two sets are the same size that will work regardless of whether the sets in questions are finite or infinite:

We say two sets A and B have the same cardinality (i.e. size) if there is a one-one function that maps A onto B.

The language here is important:

  • one-one means each element A gets mapped to a distinct element of B, so no two elements of A have the same output.
  • onto means every element of B gets "hit." In other words, the range of the function is B.

A one-one function that is also 'onto' is called a bijection or one-one correspondence

For finite sets, this should be fairly straightforward to grasp. Consider the example used above. The function is a bijection and we can match up every element of A with exactly one element of B. Moreover, every element of B has an element of A that gets mapped to it. So the sets must be the same size.

In this example of two finite sets A and B with four elements each, is just one of several possible bijections. How many possible bijections are there between A and B in this case?

There are four choices for a; once a has been mapped to an output, there are 3 choices for b; once b has been mapped to an output there are 2 choices for c. Use factorial notation to work out the value.
